awd_titl_txt: RI: Small: CompCog: Leveraging Deep Neural Networks for Understanding Human Cognition
awd_abstract_narration:
The last few years have seen significant breakthroughs in artificial intelligence and machine learning, resulting in systems that approach or even exceed human performance in interpreting pictures and words. This project explores the implications of these breakthroughs for understanding how the human mind works. Focusing on artificial neural networks, a key technology behind many recent breakthroughs that is capable of discovering novel representations for complex stimuli, the project has two goals. First, assessing the degree of correspondence between human and machine learning by examining whether the pictures or words that are similar in the representations discovered by neural network models are also judged to be similar by people. Second, developing methods for increasing this correspondence, with the goal of being able to use neural network representations to generate good predictions about how people learn and form categories using real images or text.

This research project will answer basic scientific questions about how the representations discovered by contemporary neural networks relate to human cognition. It will then explore what architectures and training regimes produce representations with these properties. In addition, the project will address the methodological question of how one can modify these representations to produce better alignment with human cognition. Answering this question will lead to powerful new tools for making models of human behavior in naturalistic contexts, leveraging the latest results in machine learning to broaden the scope of experimental research in cognitive science. By building stronger links between human and machine learning, this project will have implications for both fields. Even if current neural network systems turn out to differ significantly from human learning, they provide state-of-the-art representations for images and text that can be used as a starting point for developing better accounts of human representations. By discovering the ways in which the representations learned by artificial neural networks differ from those of humans, one can identify new algorithms and training methods that will result in a closer alignment. Since human beings remain the best examples available of systems that can solve certain problems, such an alignment offers a path toward expanding the capacities of current artificial intelligence systems and making them more interpretable by people, which is critical in settings that require human-machine interaction.

por.por_cntn:
This project explored how recent developments in the use of artificial neural networks and machine learning can be leveraged to provide insight into human cognition. The initial focus was upon artificial neural network models that have been used for vision and language, with the later addition of decision-making. 

In vision, convolutional neural networks have become a dominant approach to solving a wide range of problems, including the classification of images. The representations of images generated by these networks have been shown to capture important aspects of the content of images, and to correlate with neural activity when viewing these images. We explored how well these representations could predict human categorization decisions, incorporating these representations into standard models of how people learn and use categories. To evaluate these models, we collected a large dataset of human categorization judgments for 10,000 natural images. Our results showed that the representations produced by convolutional neural networks resulted in good predictions of human categorization judgments, and potentially provide a way to compare existing psychological models on much more naturalistic tasks. Furthermore, we showed that the data we collected on human categorization could be used to develop more robust approaches to image classification, relevant to research in computer vision.

In language, methods for constructing word embeddings based on neural networks have become extremely popular. A word embedding represents the word as a location in a high-dimensional space. One observation that has been made in the machine learning literature is that these embeddings seem to support analogical reasoning: if you take the difference between the locations of the words “man” and “woman” and then add that difference to the location of the word “king,” the resulting location is close to the word “queen.” By collecting and analyzing data on human analogy judgments we showed that this model is unable to account for how people evaluate simple analogies. People demonstrate asymmetries in their evaluation of analogies and violations of a technical condition called the triangle inequality which cannot be addressed by any purely spatial model.

Finally, we extended our approach of using neural networks to understand human behavior to the case of decision-making, where we showed that classic models of decision-making could be expressed as simple neural networks, making it possible to find the best possible instances of such models using methods developed for optimizing such networks. The resulting models can be used to test specific hypotheses about the factors that contribute to people's assessment of choices under uncertainty and to better predict human decisions.

This project has resulted in two conference papers and four journal articles in leading journals. It has also provided training for one postdoctoral researcher, two graduate students, and one undergraduate student in interdisciplinary methods at the border of psychology and computer science.
